 Well, I wasn't going to be so anal, so I aborted my previous post halfway through... But since Steeeeve responded, I'll un-censor my thoughts:
 
 A circle is the locus of coplanar points that lie some distance r from a location. As points have no dimension, and as no three points are colinear, a circle is not composed of straight lines and is therefore not a polygon. (If there were infinitely many lines, each "line" would have a length of 2πr/∞ (i.e. 0) and therefore be a point instead of a line. Further, if there were many but not infinitely many lines, any point on the line that isn't an original point -- e.g. the midpoint of one such line -- would be a distance less than r from the center of the circle.)
 The same reasoning applies to a sphere in when adding a dimension.
